thread.title: Four in 10 European doctors 'could quit UK over Brexit'
thread.title_full: Four in 10 European doctors 'could quit UK over Brexit'

author: Hatty Collier
title: Four in 10 European doctors 'could quit UK over Brexit'
text:
Thursday 23 February 2017 07:59 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard New research: A BMA survey found that 42 per cent of European doctors are thinking of leaving the UK Getty Images 
Four in 10 European doctors are considering quitting the UK following the Brexit vote, new research suggests. 
A British Medical Association (BMA) survey found that 42 per cent are thinking of leaving Britain, with a further quarter (23 per cent) still unsure. 
The BMA warned it could spell "disaster" as the NHS was already facing "crippling staff shortages". 
About 10,000 doctors who work in the NHS - 6.6 per cent of the UK medical workforce - qualified in Europe. 
The doctors' union polled 1,193 doctors from the European Economic Area (EEA) who are working in the UK. NHS chief warns frontline staff are worn out after relentless winter 
It found that they felt "less committed" to working in the UK and felt less appreciated by the Government following the referendum. 
The BMA said that recruiting from Europe had been vital in dealing with staff shortages in the health service. 
Dr Mark Porter, chairman of council at the BMA, said: "While thousands of overseas and EU doctors work across the UK to provide the best possible care for patients, many from the EU are left feeling unwelcome and uncertain about whether they and their families will have the right to live and work in the UK after Brexit. 
"These are the people who staff our hospitals and GP surgeries, look after vulnerable patients in the community and conduct vital medical research to help save lives. 
"Many have dedicated years of service to healthcare in the UK, so it's extremely concerning that so many are considering leaving. 
"At a time when the NHS is already at breaking point and facing crippling staff shortages, this would be a disaster and threaten the delivery of high-quality patient care.‚Äù 
He urged the Government to act to ensure long-term stability across the healthcare system. Read more
